## The Question

Since ancient times, controlling strategic trade routes has been both lucrative and violently contested â€” from the Strait of Salamis in 480 BC to the Strait of Kerch in 2018.

**Does globalization make conflict near these strategic locations better or worse?**

Two competing views have clashed for centuries:

:::{.callout-note icon=false}
## ðŸ”´ Lenin's View (1917)
Globalization makes strategic locations more valuable â€” and more worth fighting over. Trade and economic integration *fuel* conflict.
:::

:::{.callout-note icon=false}
## ðŸŸ¢ Montesquieu's View (1748)
Trade creates mutual dependence â€” countries prefer cooperation to keep routes open. Economic integration *curbs* conflict.
:::

This research puts both views to the test with 1.9 million observations across 30 years.

:::{.callout-important icon=false}
## The Finding
Being close to a maritime choke point **increases** conflict risk when global trade is low â€” but **decreases** it when trade is high enough. The tipping point occurs at a world trade openness of about 0.534 (share of GDP). Above that threshold, globalization protects strategic locations; below it, they become conflict magnets.
:::
